answers:
The University of Florida has various resources to address student emergencies and crises. The Student Legal Services (SLS) and Student Health Care Center (SHCC) are two key organizations that provide assistance in specific areas.

    Student Legal Services (SLS): SLS offers legal consultation and representation for certain types of cases, including landlord-tenant issues, name changes, and traffic citations. They also provide free notary services. In case of an emergency, students can contact SLS at (352) 392-1545 or visit their website at https://studentlegalservices.ufl.edu/.

    Student Health Care Center (SHCC): SHCC provides medical, mental health, and counseling services to enrolled students. In case of an emergency, students can call the SHCC at (352) 392-1161 or visit their website at https://shcc.ufl.edu/. For after-hours emergencies, students can call the SHCC after-hours line at (352) 392-1161 and press option 1.

Additionally, the University of Florida has an Emergency Management team that coordinates the university's response to various emergencies and crises. The team is responsible for developing emergency plans, conducting emergency drills, and coordinating communication during emergencies. Students can find more information about emergency preparedness and response on the UF Emergency Management website at https://emergency.ufl.edu/.

In case of a life-threatening emergency, students should call 911 immediately. For non-emergency situations, students can contact the UF Police Department at (352) 392-1111.

During a walking tour of the University of Florida, visitors can expect to experience an in-depth exploration of the campus. The tour may include visits to various academic buildings, residence halls, and facilities. Students and tour guides may share information about the history, programs, and student life at UF. Visitors will have the opportunity to learn about the different colleges, research centers, and student services available on campus. They may also get a sense of the campus culture and community. Additionally, visitors may learn about transportation options, housing, dining, and other resources for students. Overall, the walking tour aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the University of Florida and help visitors gain a better understanding of what it's like to be a student at the university.

Here are the important deadlines for submitting application materials to the University of Florida (UF) Admissions for prospective freshmen in the 2023-24 academic year, based on the context provided:

    Application Opens: August 8
    Application Due: November 1 (priority applicant round)
    Student Self-Reported Academic Record (SSAR) Due: November 15
    Submit Official Test Scores: December 1
    Freshman Admissions Decisions: February 23
    Confirm Enrollment and Pay Enrollment Deposit: May 1
    Send Official Transcripts: July 15

It's important to note that applications received after the November 1 priority deadline will be reviewed on a space-available basis, and applicants who do not submit required materials by the specified deadlines may have their applications moved into the space-available applicant pool. Additionally, students who are offered admission and wish to enroll must confirm their intentions and pay the enrollment deposit by May 1, and official transcripts must be received by July 15 to finalize enrollment.
The deadline for prospective freshmen to submit their official transcripts in order to finalize their enrollment at UF for the 2023-24 academic year is July 15.

Parents of dependent undergraduate students at the University of Florida can apply for educational loans through the Federal Direct PLUS loan program by following these steps:

    The student must first complete and submit the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) at http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/applying/ as soon as possible after October 1.
    Once the student has been admitted to UF and their financial aid package has been offered, the parent can log in to their FAFSA account at https://studentaid.gov/ using their FSA ID.
    The parent should select "Request a PLUS Loan" and follow the prompts to complete the application process.
    If the parent is denied a PLUS loan due to adverse credit history, they may be able to appeal the denial or obtain an endorser or co-signer.
    Once the loan is approved, the parent will receive instructions on how to complete the Master Promissory Note (MPN) and entrance counseling.

To find the available financial aid item types disbursed out of a specific department in the Student Information System at the University of Florida, users can follow these steps:

    Log in to the Student Information System using your UFID and password.
    Navigate to the "Student Services and Financial Aid" tab.
    Select "Award Information" or "Financial Aid Offers" to view your financial aid package.
    Look for the "Cost of Attendance" or "Budget" section, which lists the various expenses covered by financial aid.
    Check the "Department" column to identify the specific department for each expense or financial aid item.
    If you want to view all financial aid disbursements for a particular department, you can filter or search for that department in the system.

Alternatively, you can contact the Financial Aid Office or the specific department for more detailed information about the financial aid items and their disbursement.

Keep in mind that the Student Information System may have different interfaces and navigation options depending on the version and configuration. If you have trouble finding the information, consult the system documentation or contact the IT support for assistance.

The Division of Student Life at the University of Florida offers various facilities and services to enhance the student experience. Some of these include:

    Welcome Center: Located next to the Reitz Union, the Welcome Center is maintained by the Ofﬁce of Admissions and provides weekday and Saturday information sessions and walking tours of campus.
    Career Connections Center: Helps students explore career options, build professional skills, and connect with employers.
    Center for Inclusion & Multicultural Engagement: Provides programs and resources that promote diversity, equity, and inclusion.
    Counseling and Wellness Center: Offers mental health counseling, psychiatric services, and wellness programs.
    Brown Center for Leadership & Service: Provides opportunities for students to develop leadership skills and engage in community service.
    Disability Resource Center: Offers support services, assistive technology, student involvement opportunities, events, and scholarships for students with disabilities.
    Housing and Residence Life: Provides on-campus housing options and related services.
    Reitz Student Union: Offers programs and services that create a unique student experience, including the Arts & Crafts Center, Game Room, Career Connections Center, and more.
    Machen Florida Opportunity Scholars Program: Provides academic, social, and financial support to underrepresented students.
    Student Activities & Involvement: Offers opportunities for students to get involved in campus life through student organizations, events, and programs.
    Student Government: Represents the student body and advocates for student interests.
    Sorority & Fraternity Life: Provides support and resources for students involved in Greek life.
    Student Legal Services: Provides free legal advice and representation to students on a variety of issues.
    GatorLink: Establishes a unique computer identity for students and provides access to all online university services.
    GatorOne Card: The official university photo ID that provides access to various campus facilities and services.
    UFID: An eight-digit number that serves as the primary identifier for all university records and transactions.

These are just some of the facilities and services offered by the Division of Student Life at the University of Florida. For more information, students can visit the division's website or contact the specific office or service they are interested in.

The University of Florida Police Department (UFPD) provides various services to ensure campus safety and security for students, faculty, staff, and campus visitors. These services include:

    Uniformed Patrol Division: UFPD officers are highly trained campus law enforcement professionals who patrol the UF campus and its surrounding properties 24 hours a day, every day. They are equipped with contemporary crime-fighting techniques and tools.
    Criminal Investigations Division: The department has a team of highly trained detectives to investigate any reported crime on campus.
    Community Services Division: The division is proactive in providing the campus community with information regarding personal and property protection through classes, programs, and documents.
    Emergency Response: UFPD responds to emergency situations on campus and provides emergency services as needed.
    Crime Prevention: UFPD offers various crime prevention programs and resources to help students, faculty, and staff stay safe on campus.
    Traffic Enforcement: UFPD enforces traffic laws on campus and provides traffic safety education and awareness programs.
    Emergency Notifications: UFPD uses various methods to notify the campus community of emergencies or potential threats to safety.
    Collaboration with Other Agencies: UFPD works closely with other law enforcement agencies, emergency responders, and university departments to ensure campus safety and security.

Overall, the UFPD is committed to maintaining a safe and secure campus environment and encourages everyone to be aware of their surroundings and report any suspicious activity.

Establishing a new center or institute at the University of Florida can contribute to public service in several ways. One way is through public-private partnerships that provide opportunities for students, such as assistantships and service learning. For instance, the center or institute may collaborate with local organizations or industries to offer students practical experience and real-world applications of their academic knowledge.

Another way the center or institute can contribute to public service is by generating interdisciplinary resources and attracting postdoctoral fellows. These resources and fellows can conduct research that addresses pressing public issues and provides solutions to community problems. Additionally, the center or institute may establish a lecture series or design courses that engage the public and promote lifelong learning.

The planned activities for the center or institute should be described in detail in the proposal. For example, the center may focus on collaborative research in a specific area, such as sustainability or health, and apply for external funding to support this research. The center may also provide greater focus and depth to a research area, creating a core service facility or offering specialized training to students and professionals.

The advantages of the center or institute to the University and reporting unit should also be highlighted. For instance, the center may satisfy unmet needs by offering unique resources or expertise that are not currently available at UF. The center may also enhance the University's reputation and attract external funding, which can benefit the entire institution.

The reporting structure and administrative structure of the center or institute should be clearly outlined in the proposal. The center should report to the relevant dean or vice president, depending on its scope and focus. The center should also have a director and an advisory committee to oversee its operations and ensure alignment with the University's mission and objectives.

Finally, all members of the center, their academic affiliations, and areas of expertise should be listed in an appendix document. This information can help demonstrate the center's commitment to interdisciplinary collaboration and its potential impact on public service.
The Florida Voluntary Prekindergarten Education Program (VPK) offers free pre-K education for all Florida 4-year-olds regardless of income.

Information sessions are an essential part of campus visits at the University of Florida as they are conducted by the Office of Admissions at the Welcome Center, which is located next to the Reitz Union. These sessions provide visitors with valuable information about the university, including weekday and Saturday tours of the campus. The Welcome Center serves as the university's front door to visitors and is an excellent starting point for individuals who are considering attending UF. For more information about visiting the campus, interested individuals can refer to the university's admissions website.

The UF Libraries do not specifically have separate sections mentioned in the context provided for study spaces, research assistance, equipment rentals, interlibrary loan, free printing, legal services, notary services, and passport services. However, the libraries offer various resources and services that may include some of these facilities.

For study spaces, the libraries provide quiet study areas, group study rooms, and collaborative spaces. Students can check the library website for more information on available study spaces and their reservation policies.

Research assistance is available through the libraries' research and information desk services. Students can get help with finding information, using databases, and citing sources.

Equipment rentals may be available through the libraries' media services. Students can check the library website or contact their specific library for more information on equipment rentals.

Interlibrary loan and document delivery services allow students to borrow materials from other libraries or request copies of articles or chapters that are not available in the UF Libraries.

Free printing is available at most libraries, and students can check the library website for more information on printing policies and locations.

Legal services, notary services, and passport services are not mentioned in the context provided as being offered by the UF Libraries. However, students can check the library website or contact the university's Student Legal Services, Notary Services, or Passport Services for more information on these services.

Community engagement opportunities may be available through the libraries' events and programs. Students can check the library website for more information on upcoming events and opportunities to get involved.

Note: Goals/Activity information should be included fo r each university when more than one university is affiliated with an institute/center.    d. Position Data  Provide an organizational chart that delineates the f unctions of all faculty and staff and includes any advisory boards. Provide a list of current advisory board members. Also provide copies of relevant governance documents.  For proposals involving more th an one institution, include such information for each participating institution as well as giving the Statewide structure.     Annual Reports for the State of Florida Centers/Institut es should be sent to the appropriate State agency with a copy to the Office of Institutional Planning and Research.    C.  Additional Reporting Requirements for University of Florida Centers/Institutes   In addition to the information submitted through the Expe rtnet system to the BOG, UF Centers /Institutes are required to provide annual reports as required by the Dean  of the College to whom they report.  The format and information required for these reports are specified by the Deans of the respective colleges.     VI. Guidelines for Evaluation of Centers and Institutes     The University administration will evaluate Centers/Institutes on a cyclical basis.  The Provost and Vice President for Research will evaluate each State of Fl orida Center/Institute every three (3) years.  Deans will evaluate the University of Florida Centers/Institutes assigned to their respective colleges every five (5) years.      The submission DEADLINE for all evaluations will be approximately April 15 of each year.  The Office of Institutional Planning and Research maintain s the schedule of evaluations of all Centers and Institutes, and will coordinate the process with the r espective deans and the office of the Vice President for Research.  Completed evaluations should be uploaded to the evaluation web site http://www.ir.ufl.edu/oirapps/centersandinstitutes/. (Please note, this differs from the annual reporting coordinated by the Office of Institutional Planning and Research).       Evaluations will focus on the mission and stated objec tives of the Center/Institute.  The evaluator should consider the following items as they evaluate their i ndividual Centers/Institutes. next to the Reitz Union. The Welcome Center is maintained by the Ofﬁce of Admissions and is the university's front door to visitors, providing weekday and Saturday information sessions and walking tours of campus.  More Info (http://www.admissions.ufl.edu/visit.html)

at the University of Florida. On-campus living means students are in on all the action and seconds away from everything as they get involved, build the path to their successful future, and make connections that will last a lifetime. UF Housing offers 27 different residence and four different Graduate and Family Housing Villages.  More Info (http://www.housing.ufl.edu/) Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0753 ) First Year Students Newly admitted students will be offered a Student Housing Agreement based on the term they were admitted. Agreements are available for the academic year (Summer B/Fall/Spring, Fall/Spring, Spring/Summer, and the Summer terms). Housing is not reserved for ﬁrst-year students. To secure campus housing, the students must apply for housing and sign a Student Housing Agreement before the posted deadline. •Residence Halls  (https://www.housing.ufl.edu/housing/) •Apply for Housing  (http://www.housing.ufl.edu/apply/) •Graduate and Family Housing (https://housing.ufl.edu/living-options/?housing-type=family-housing ) •Off-Campus Housing Information  (http://www.offcampus.ufl.edu/) Student Financial Aid and Scholarships The Ofﬁce of Student Financial Aid and Scholarships (SFA) in S107 Criser Hall administers ﬁnancial aid programs. SFA awards aid according to ﬁnancial need.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/)Student Life 5 Financial Aid Financial aid is money provided to students and their families as gift aid (scholarships, grants) or self-help programs (loans and/or work) to help pay college costs. Financial aid can be awarded singly (one type of aid) or as a package.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/) Grants Grants are awarded based on ﬁnancial need. The largest grant program at UF is the Federal Pell Grant. Other grants include Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grants, Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grant, Florida Student Assistance Grants, UF Excellence Grant, UF Undergraduate Grant and UF Graduate Grants.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/grants/) Scholarships Scholarships are awarded based on academic performance and /or ﬁnancial need. Most scholarships are awarded through the SFA and individual UF colleges. SFA administers a limited number of scholarships from private donors.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/scholarships/) Student Employment Federal Work-Study jobs may be awarded by SFA to students with demonstrated ﬁnancial need as part of an aid

Repair stations are located across campus, though they aren’t always working .  • Gainesville has several good bike shops .  Student Nighttime Auxiliary Patrol (SNAP):  https://taps.ufl.edu/alternative -transportation/snap/   • Free nighttime shuttle van .  • On-demand service, stops are mostly on campus and midtown and some larger off -campus apartment  complexes .  Parking:  https://taps.u fl.edu/permits/   • Student parking pass costs $160/year .  • Parking on the main campus may be limited during peak hours .  • Pay close attention to color codes/signs to avoid parking tickets!   Additional transportation options:  Campus Cab, Campus Connector, Gator Lift Paratransit, E -scooters,  carpooling, etc.: https://taps.ufl.edu/alternative -transportation/       3  3 Food   Hitchcock Field & Fork Pantry:  https://pantry.fieldandfork.ufl.edu/   • Free for all UF students, faculty & staff .  • No questions asked .  Krishna Lunch:  https://krishnalunch.com/krishna -lunch/   • Cheap vegan lunch ($6/meal  or less with meal ticket packs) .  • At Plaza of the Americas when class is in session .  • You can fill Tupperware at no extra cost, don’t be afraid to ask for larger portions!   Bread of the Mighty Food Bank:  https://breadofthemighty.org/   Farmers Markets:  https://worklife.hr.ufl.edu/farmers -markets/   • High quality fresh local produce .  • Also meat, baked goods, honey, and crafts .  4 Grants and Scholarships   SNRE page on financial support:  https://snre.ifas.ufl.edu/academics/graduate/financial -support/   Graduate Student Council Travel Grants: https://sg.ufl.edu/resources/gsc/grants/   • Available frequently for conference or professional development travel .  • Easy application, but take care to follow purchasing guidelines. No PCard reimbursements allowed .  CALS Scholarship:  https://cals.ufl.edu/current -students/scholarships/   • Simple application, letter of recommendation required .  • Funds are paid directly to students .  UF Biodiversity Institute Fellowship:  https://biodiversity.research.ufl.edu/fellows/get -to-know -our- fellows.html   Pivot Funding Database:  https://research.ufl.edu/f inding -funding/cos -pivot -funding -database.html   • Good place to search for funding opportunities from a wide variety of sources .      4  5 Health + Wellness   Gator Gradcare:  https://gatorcare.org/gatorgradcare/   • Inexpensive health insurance for graduate assistants with at least 0.25 FTE appointment .  • Includes limited dental benefits:

FRESHMAN DATES & DEADLINES Keep this list of important dates so you do not miss a deadline. 2023-24 AUG8Application Opens August 8Prospective freshmen can apply using the Common Application.  NOV1Application Due November 1Applications must be received by UF Admissions no later than 11:59 p.m. EST on November 1 for consideration in the priority applicant round. Applications received after this date will be reviewed on a space-available basis, with a final deadline of March 1. NOV15Student Self-Reported Academic Record (SSAR) November 15If your SSAR is not received by the November 15 deadline, your application will be moved into the space-available applicant pool. DEC1Submit Official Test Scores December 1ACT or SAT scores may be sent directly from the testing agency or self-reported through your application status page. If your test scores are not received by the deadline, your application will be moved into the space-available applicant pool. Applicants who self-report scores and are admitted to UF must submit official test scores by December 1. FEB23Freshman Admissions Decisions February 23You can access your admissions decision via the Check Status application portal. Official written notifications of acceptance are mailed to admitted students only.  M AY1Confirm Enrollment May 1If you have been admitted into the freshman class and wish to enroll, confirm your intentions and pay your enrollment deposit no later than May 1 via your Check Status application portal. JUL15Send Official Transcripts July 15 If you are enrolling at UF, official transcript(s) for your high school and any colleges you have attended must be received by July 15 so that UF may finalize your enrollment.SEND YOUR TRANSCRIPTS TO:The UF Office of AdmissionsP. O. Box 114000Gainesville, FL 32611-4000 OFFICE OF ADMISSIONS PO Box 114000, Gainesville, FL 32611-4000 admissions.ufl.eduNeed more information?admissions.ufl.edu/apply/freshman

The largest grant program at UF is the Federal Pell Grant. Other grants include Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grants, Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grant, Florida Student Assistance Grants, UF Excellence Grant, UF Undergraduate Grant and UF Graduate Grants. Work-Study jobs may be awarded by SFA to students with demonstrated ﬁnancial need as part of an aid package. Other job programs, such as OPS employment, do not require ﬁnancial need and are open to any student with the desire to work who meets the basic criteria of half-time enrollment and a 2.0 GPA. Student jobs usually are 15-20 hours a week and pay at least minimum wage.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/employment/) Loans Loan programs include Federal Direct loans, Federal Direct Unsubsidized loans, Federal Direct PLUS loans, and UF institutional loans. These programs offer long-term, low-interest loans that must be repaid when the borrower graduates, withdraws, or drops to less than half-time enrollment. Parents of dependent undergraduate students can take out educational loans through the Federal Direct PLUS loan program.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/loans/) When to Apply The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FASFA) is available October 1 each year. Although SFA cannot award ﬁnancial aid until students have been admitted to UF, they should apply for aid as soon as possible on or after October 1. •How to Apply for Financial Aid  (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/applying/) •Enrollment Requirements for Financial Aid (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/receiving/enrollment-requirements/) •How to Apply for Student Employment (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/employment/) Financial Aid Academic Progress Requirements UF students receiving ﬁnancial aid are required to be in good standing and to maintain satisfactory academic progress.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/additional/academic-progress/) Recreational Sports With a vibrant student community and ample sunshine, campus life revolves around recreation. With ﬁfty plus intramural and sport clubs, holistic wellness services, and its very own lakefront, UF RecSports is the premier destination for Gators seeking to get an active lifestyle. RecSports offers experiences that enrich the lives of University of Florida students through excellence in facilities, ﬁtness, sport, adventure, and play. RecSports enhances the UF community by encouraging the development of the whole person, inspires self-discovery, and fosters a sense of belonging through inclusive recreational experiences.  More Info (http://www.recsports.ufl.edu/) Locations  (http://recsports.ufl.edu/locations/) Student Health Care Center More Info (http://shcc.ufl.edu/ ) Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0018 ) General Information and

at the University of Florida. On-campus living means students are in on all the action and seconds away from everything as they get involved, build the path to their successful future, and make connections that will last a lifetime. UF Housing offers 27 different residence and four different Graduate and Family Housing Villages.  More Info (http://www.housing.ufl.edu/) Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0753 ) First Year Students Newly admitted students will be offered a Student Housing Agreement based on the term they were admitted. Agreements are available for the academic year (Summer B/Fall/Spring, Fall/Spring, Spring/Summer, and the Summer terms). Housing is not reserved for ﬁrst-year students. To secure campus housing, the students must apply for housing and sign a Student Housing Agreement before the posted deadline. •Residence Halls  (https://www.housing.ufl.edu/housing/) •Apply for Housing  (http://www.housing.ufl.edu/apply/) •Graduate and Family Housing (https://housing.ufl.edu/living-options/?housing-type=family-housing ) •Off-Campus Housing Information  (http://www.offcampus.ufl.edu/) Student Financial Aid and Scholarships The Ofﬁce of Student Financial Aid and Scholarships (SFA) in S107 Criser Hall administers ﬁnancial aid programs. SFA awards aid according to ﬁnancial need.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/)Student Life 5 Financial Aid Financial aid is money provided to students and their families as gift aid (scholarships, grants) or self-help programs (loans and/or work) to help pay college costs. Financial aid can be awarded singly (one type of aid) or as a package.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/) Grants Grants are awarded based on ﬁnancial need. The largest grant program at UF is the Federal Pell Grant. Other grants include Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grants, Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grant, Florida Student Assistance Grants, UF Excellence Grant, UF Undergraduate Grant and UF Graduate Grants.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/grants/) Scholarships Scholarships are awarded based on academic performance and /or ﬁnancial need. Most scholarships are awarded through the SFA and individual UF colleges. SFA administers a limited number of scholarships from private donors.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/scholarships/) Student Employment Federal Work-Study jobs may be awarded by SFA to students with demonstrated ﬁnancial need as part of an aid

Additional Reporting Requirements for University of Florida Centers/Institutes   In addition to the information submitted through the Expe rtnet system to the BOG, UF Centers /Institutes are required to provide annual reports as required by the Dean  of the College to whom they report.  The format and information required for these reports are specified by the Deans of the respective colleges.     VI. Guidelines for Evaluation of Centers and Institutes     The University administration will evaluate Centers/Institutes on a cyclical basis.  The Provost and Vice President for Research will evaluate each State of Fl orida Center/Institute every three (3) years.  Deans will evaluate the University of Florida Centers/Institutes assigned to their respective colleges every five (5) years.      The submission DEADLINE for all evaluations will be approximately April 15 of each year.  The Office of Institutional Planning and Research maintain s the schedule of evaluations of all Centers and Institutes, and will coordinate the process with the r espective deans and the office of the Vice President for Research.  Completed evaluations should be uploaded to the evaluation web site http://www.ir.ufl.edu/oirapps/centersandinstitutes/. (Please note, this differs from the annual reporting coordinated by the Office of Institutional Planning and Research). Student Life 1 STUDENT LIFE Student Services Division of Student Life The University of Florida Division of Student Life cultivates a comprehensively excellent student experience that prepares Gators to engage, transform, and thrive in an evolving global community. The Ofﬁce of the Vice President for Student Life, located in 135 Tigert Hall, has administrative responsibility for: •Career Connections Center •Center for Inclusion & Multicultural Engagement •Center for New Student & Family Programs •Counseling and Wellness Center •David and Wanda Brown Center for Leadership & Service •Dean of Students Ofﬁce •Disability Resource Center •GatorWell Health Promotion Services •Housing and Residence Life •J. Wayne Reitz Union •Machen Florida Opportunity Scholars Program •Off Campus Life •Recreational Sports •Student Activities & Involvement •Student Government Advising & Operations •Sorority & Fraternity Life •Student Legal Services More Info (http://www.ufsa.ufl.edu/)Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0026 ) Campus Facilities Newell Hall Originally built in 1909, Newell Hall is the 3rd oldest building on campus. The facility was renovated to create a state-of-the-art active learning environment for both undergraduate and graduate students. It provides a high-tech, collaborative environment with open plan study rooms to foster a creative environment focused on innovation, flexibility, and accessibility.  Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0013 ) Reitz Student Union The Reitz Union is the University of Florida’s student union. The Reitz Union offers programs and services that create a unique Gator student experience. The facility is home to the Arts & Crafts Center, Game Room, Reitz Union Hotel, The Gallery, and Ofﬁce of Event Services. It is also home to the Brown Center for Leadership & Service, the Career Connections Center, the Center for Inclusion & Multicultural Engagement, GatorWell Health Promotion Services, Machen Florida Opportunity Scholars, Student Activities and Involvement, Sorority & Fraternity Life, Student Government, Student Legal Services, UF Bookstore, Reitz Union Barbershop, Wells Fargo, SG Bike Repair, study spaces, meeting rooms, dance studios, lounge spaces and more.##  More Info (https://union.ufl.edu/ )Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0686 ) Ben Hill Grifﬁn Stadium Ben Hill Grifﬁn Stadium, or The Swamp , is widely recognized as one of the toughest environments for a visiting team in all of college football. Several facelifts after

Gators thrive and have a transformative student experiences. In addition to accommodations, the Disability Resource Center provides: •Support Services •Assistive Technology •Student Involvement Opportunities •Events •Scholarships •And so much more! Contact: Email  (DRCaccessuf@ufsa.ufl.edu )| 352.392.8565 4  Student Life More Info (https://disability.ufl.edu/) Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0020 ) Florida Fresh Dining Florida Fresh Dining at the University of Florida is the ofﬁcial food service provider for the university and offers severalmeal plans  (https:// dineoncampus.com/UF/meal-plan-options/ ).  More Info (https://dineoncampus.com/uf/ ) GatorLink | GatorOne Card | UFID GatorLink GatorLink establishes a unique computer identity for every student. The GatorLink account provides access to all online services and creates the UF "username@ufl.edu"  email address.  More Info (http://helpdesk.ufl.edu/self-help/new-gator-resources/gatorlink/) All students must maintain and regularly check their GatorLink email as this is where all ofﬁcial university communications are sent. GatorOne Card The GatorOne card is the ofﬁcial university photo ID. The ID Card Services ofﬁce is located on the ground floor of the UF Bookstore and Welcome Center complex on Museum Road.  More Info (https://businessservices.ufl.edu/services/gator-1-card/) All enrolled students, faculty and staff must have this card to: •Enter CIRCA computer labs, university libraries, the inﬁrmary, recreation centers. •Sign up for intramural sports activities. •Participate in the textbook deferment program at the UF Bookstore. •Purchase tickets to university events. •Vote in Student Government elections. •Purchase food on campus with a Gator Dining or prepaid vending account. •Use as an ATM/debit card when activated through Wells Fargo Bank.  More Info (https://www.wellsfargo.com/student/banking/campuscard/) UFID UFID is an eight-digit number that serves as the primary identiﬁer for all university records and transactions. Like a social security number, no two people will have the same number, and each person has only one. The UFID is assigned by the university, not chosen like a PIN. All students, faculty and staff have UFIDs, and the number is printed on the GatorOne card.  More Info (http://identity.it.ufl.edu/process/uf-identiﬁer/) Housing and Residence Life Welcome to where Gators live at the University of Florida. On-campus living means students are in on all the action and seconds

for all students, faculty and staff, and campus visitors. The UFPD has the utmost concern for personal and property safety, but with an open campus environment, safety becomes a shared responsibility. The UFPD is a state of Florida and nationally accredited law enforcement agency. There are more than 90 fully certiﬁed and sworn ofﬁcers who patrol the UF campus and its surrounding properties 24 hours per day, every day. The department has its own Criminal Investigations Division employing highly trained detectives to investigate any reported crime on campus. The ofﬁcers of the Uniformed Patrol Division are highly trained campus law enforcement professionals who are equipped with the most contemporary crime-ﬁghting techniques and tools. The Community Services Division is proactive in providing everyone in the campus community with the very latest information regarding personal and property protection through classes, programs and documents.  More Info (http://www.police.ufl.edu/) Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0027 ) Career Connections Center The Career Connections Center (C3) is the University of Florida’s comprehensive career services operation responsible for providing world class career and professional development for all students. As the # 2 Career Center in the country according to Best Colleges, the C3 prepares students for contributions in work, citizenship, and life. The center supports the overall student experience starting during Preview and moving beyond graduation. The C3’s mission is to educate and create connections for the University of Florida community to facilitate the holistic career development of students. The center provides a variety of services, tools, networks, and events for UF students and alumni. Whether exploring career options, developing professional skills, ﬁnding meaningful experience, or preparing for life after graduation, the C3 is there to help students on their unique journey. Through the university’s Career Pathways initiative, students can access customized information, connections, and programs to personalize their professional development experience and community. It's recommended that UF students engage early and often with the Career Connections Center to enhance their University of Florida experience and post-graduation success.  More Info (https://career.ufl.edu/) Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0686 ) Visit the Career Connections Center to: •Assess skills and interests to help select a major

Additional Reporting Requirements for University of Florida Centers/Institutes   In addition to the information submitted through the Expe rtnet system to the BOG, UF Centers /Institutes are required to provide annual reports as required by the Dean  of the College to whom they report.  The format and information required for these reports are specified by the Deans of the respective colleges.     VI. Guidelines for Evaluation of Centers and Institutes     The University administration will evaluate Centers/Institutes on a cyclical basis.  The Provost and Vice President for Research will evaluate each State of Fl orida Center/Institute every three (3) years.  Deans will evaluate the University of Florida Centers/Institutes assigned to their respective colleges every five (5) years.      The submission DEADLINE for all evaluations will be approximately April 15 of each year.  The Office of Institutional Planning and Research maintain s the schedule of evaluations of all Centers and Institutes, and will coordinate the process with the r espective deans and the office of the Vice President for Research.  Completed evaluations should be uploaded to the evaluation web site http://www.ir.ufl.edu/oirapps/centersandinstitutes/. (Please note, this differs from the annual reporting coordinated by the Office of Institutional Planning and Research).       Evaluations will focus on the mission and stated objec tives of the Center/Institute.  The evaluator should consider the following items as they evaluate their i ndividual Centers/Institutes. Additional

All three elemen ts are not required for a center to be established but should be identified when they are anticipated to be part of the mission.   D.  Proposed Activities: Describe the activities that are planned for the center (e.g., collaborative research on the topic of (X); the intent to generate interdisciplinary resources, to design courses, to develop an interdisciplinary graduate program, attract postdoctora l fellows, create a lecture series; to establish a core service facility, provide greater focus and depth to a r esearch area, etc.). Explain the plans to apply for external funding and identify the relationship of the center's activities with those of departments and/or other centers. Describe the advantages of the center over current structure (what unmet needs will be satisfied by having the center?) and the value of the center to the University and to the reporting unit. Describe, where possible, the synergistic and collaborative efforts existing amongst the members of the  proposed center.  Also describe their record in successfully garnering extramural funds.     E.   Reporting Structure: The proposal for a new cente r or institute must include a reporting structure and describe the logic of that structure at UF.  In particular, the proposal should outline to whom and through whom the center or institute reports.  The proposal s hould demonstrate appropriate levels of commitment and interest from relevant departments, colleges, or other stakeholders.     A new center or institute will in general, report to the dean of the college unless it is a campus-wide center or institute in which case it would report to th e relevant Vice President (Vice President Health Affairs, Vice President IFAS, Vice President for Research or the Provost ).  Any campus-wide centers should be discussed with the relevant vice president(s) prior to producing a proposal.  F.   Administrative structure: The position of the cente r/institute within the University/college/department must be explained with the lines of accountability and responsibility clearly indicated. Each center should design its own administrative structure in consultatio n with the relevant department chair(s) and dean. However, it is expected that each center/institute will have at a minimum, a director and an advisory committee.       4. Center Membership All members of the center, their academic affiliations, and area(s) of expertise, should be listed in an appendix document.   G.   The

Community Weatherization Coalition Home Energy Tune -ups:  https://communityweatheriza tion.org/tune - up-application/   • Home visit or DIY kit to help Alachua County residents save on utility bills .  • They provide energy -efficient lightbulb, water saving attachments, and pipe insulation . public schools; public-private partnerships); opportunities for students (e.g., assistantships, service learning); or financial goals (e.g ., levels of external funding, potential contracts).  Note: Goals/Activity information should be included fo r each university when more than one university is affiliated with an institute/center.    d. Position Data  Provide an organizational chart that delineates the f unctions of all faculty and staff and includes any advisory boards. Provide a list of current advisory board members. Also provide copies of relevant governance documents.  For proposals involving more th an one institution, include such information for each participating institution as well as giving the Statewide structure.     Annual Reports for the State of Florida Centers/Institut es should be sent to the appropriate State agency with a copy to the Office of Institutional Planning and Research.    C.  Additional Reporting Requirements for University of Florida Centers/Institutes   In addition to the information submitted through the Expe rtnet system to the BOG, UF Centers /Institutes are required to provide annual reports as required by the Dean  of the College to whom they report.  The format and information required for these reports are specified by the Deans of the respective colleges.     VI. Guidelines for Evaluation of Centers and Institutes     The University administration will evaluate Centers/Institutes on a cyclical basis.  The Provost and Vice President for Research will evaluate each State of Fl orida Center/Institute every three (3) years.  Deans will evaluate the University of Florida Centers/Institutes assigned to their respective colleges every five (5) years.      The submission DEADLINE for all evaluations will be approximately April 15 of each year.  The Office of Institutional Planning and Research maintain s the schedule of evaluations of all Centers and Institutes, and will coordinate the process with the r espective deans and the office of the Vice President for Research.  Completed evaluations should be uploaded to the evaluation web site http://www.ir.ufl.edu/oirapps/centersandinstitutes/. (Please note, this differs from the annual reporting coordinated by the Office of Institutional Planning and Research).       Evaluations will focus on the mission and stated objec tives of the Center/Institute.  The evaluator should consider the following items as they evaluate their i ndividual Centers/Institutes. Additional

Gators thrive and have a transformative student experiences. In addition to accommodations, the Disability Resource Center provides: •Support Services •Assistive Technology •Student Involvement Opportunities •Events •Scholarships •And so much more! Contact: Email  (DRCaccessuf@ufsa.ufl.edu )| 352.392.8565 4  Student Life More Info (https://disability.ufl.edu/) Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0020 ) Florida Fresh Dining Florida Fresh Dining at the University of Florida is the ofﬁcial food service provider for the university and offers several meal plans  (https:// dineoncampus.com/UF/meal-plan-options/ ).  More Info (https://dineoncampus.com/uf/ ) GatorLink | GatorOne Card | UFID GatorLink GatorLink establishes a unique computer identity for every student. The GatorLink account provides access to all online services and creates the UF "username@ufl.edu"  email address.  More Info (http://helpdesk.ufl.edu/self-help/new-gator-resources/gatorlink/) All students must maintain and regularly check their GatorLink email as this is where all ofﬁcial university communications are sent. GatorOne Card The GatorOne card is the ofﬁcial university photo ID. The ID Card Services ofﬁce is located on the ground floor of the UF Bookstore and Welcome Center complex on Museum Road.  More Info (https://businessservices.ufl.edu/services/gator-1-card/) All enrolled students, faculty and staff must have this card to: •Enter CIRCA computer labs, university libraries, the inﬁrmary, recreation centers. •Sign up for intramural sports activities. •Participate in the textbook deferment program at the UF Bookstore. •Purchase tickets to university events. •Vote in Student Government elections. •Purchase food on campus with a Gator Dining or prepaid vending account. •Use as an ATM/debit card when activated through Wells Fargo Bank.  More Info (https://www.wellsfargo.com/student/banking/campuscard/) UFID UFID is an eight-digit number that serves as the primary identiﬁer for all university records and transactions. Like a social security number, no two people will have the same number, and each person has only one. The UFID is assigned by the university, not chosen like a PIN. All students, faculty and staff have UFIDs, and the number is printed on the GatorOne card.  More Info (http://identity.it.ufl.edu/process/uf-identiﬁer/) Housing and Residence Life Welcome to where Gators live at the University of Florida. On-campus living means students are in on all the action and seconds

next to the Reitz Union. The Welcome Center is maintained by the Ofﬁce of Admissions and is the university's front door to visitors, providing weekday and Saturday information sessions and walking tours of campus.  More Info (http://www.admissions.ufl.edu/visit.html)

at the University of Florida. On-campus living means students are in on all the action and seconds away from everything as they get involved, build the path to their successful future, and make connections that will last a lifetime. UF Housing offers 27 different residence and four different Graduate and Family Housing Villages.  More Info (http://www.housing.ufl.edu/) Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0753 ) First Year Students Newly admitted students will be offered a Student Housing Agreement based on the term they were admitted. Agreements are available for the academic year (Summer B/Fall/Spring, Fall/Spring, Spring/Summer, and the Summer terms). Housing is not reserved for ﬁrst-year students. To secure campus housing, the students must apply for housing and sign a Student Housing Agreement before the posted deadline. •Residence Halls  (https://www.housing.ufl.edu/housing/) •Apply for Housing  (http://www.housing.ufl.edu/apply/) •Graduate and Family Housing (https://housing.ufl.edu/living-options/?housing-type=family-housing ) •Off-Campus Housing Information  (http://www.offcampus.ufl.edu/) Student Financial Aid and Scholarships The Ofﬁce of Student Financial Aid and Scholarships (SFA) in S107 Criser Hall administers ﬁnancial aid programs. SFA awards aid according to ﬁnancial need.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/)Student Life 5 Financial Aid Financial aid is money provided to students and their families as gift aid (scholarships, grants) or self-help programs (loans and/or work) to help pay college costs. Financial aid can be awarded singly (one type of aid) or as a package.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/) Grants Grants are awarded based on ﬁnancial need. The largest grant program at UF is the Federal Pell Grant. Other grants include Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grants, Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grant, Florida Student Assistance Grants, UF Excellence Grant, UF Undergraduate Grant and UF Graduate Grants.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/grants/) Scholarships Scholarships are awarded based on academic performance and /or ﬁnancial need. Most scholarships are awarded through the SFA and individual UF colleges. SFA administers a limited number of scholarships from private donors.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/scholarships/) Student Employment Federal Work-Study jobs may be awarded by SFA to students with demonstrated ﬁnancial need as part of an aid
